description:
Hypoxylon fragiforme is a species of ascomycete fungus that belongs to the family Hypoxylaceae. It is a saprobic organism, meaning it feeds on decaying organic matter, primarily on the bark and wood of various deciduous tree species.

The fruiting bodies of H. fragiforme are known as stromata, which are cushion-shaped or conical structures that emerge from the bark of the host tree. The stromata are typically reddish-brown or purple-black in color and have a velvety or powdery texture.

Under the microscope, the fungus produces small, dark brown to black, elliptical to cylindrical ascospores within specialized structures called asci. These ascospores are the primary means of reproduction and dispersal for the fungus.

H. fragiforme is commonly found in temperate and boreal forests throughout the Northern Hemisphere, where it plays an important role in the decomposition of dead and decaying wood, contributing to the nutrient cycling within forest ecosystems.
